titleStmt.title: The plouumans tale compylled by syr Geffrey Chaucher knyght

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A09916 of text S115045 in the English Short Title Catalog (STC 20178). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 61 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 32 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The plouumans tale compylled by syr Geffrey Chaucher knyght
titleStmt.author: Chaucer, Geoffrey, d. 1400, attributed name.
Brampton, Thomas, fl. 1414, attributed name.

publicationStmt.publisher: In Paules churche yarde at the sygne of the Hyll by Wyllyam Hyll,

notesStmt.note: Not in fact by Chaucer. Also misattributed to Thomas Brampton. "A.N. Wawn, Yearbook of English studies, 2 (1972) 21-40, and BJRL, 56 (1973) 174-92, argues that the work was originally a Lollard tract written in the early 15th century, subsequently revised and gaining the addition of the prologue and lines 205-28 in the 16th century"--Halkett & Laing (3rd ed.).
Publisher's name from colophon; publication date conjectured by STC.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
